questions.text:
1. In the given organ identify its parts:

* Ureter

* Vas deferens

* Prostate

* Seminal vesicle

* Urethra
questions.solution:
1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c is the correctly matched option. In the given image, the marked structure

* 1 is vas deferens

* 2 is ureter

* 3 is seminal vesicle

* 4 is prostate



The gross image below shows the posterior view of prostate, vas deferens, and seminal vesicle:

questions.text: 2. Which one of the following is the action of the muscle attached in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the dorsal surface of the sacral bone. The muscle attached in the marked structure is the gluteus maximus and its action is abduction at hip. 

The gluteus maximus originates from the posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament. It inserts primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface. 

It is a large, quadrilateral powerful muscle covering mainly the posterior surface of pelvis and supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2). It is the chief extensor of the thigh at the hip joint. This action is very important in rising from a sitting position and for maintaining the erect posture. Other actions include lateral rotation of the thigh and abduction of the thigh at the hip joint (by upper fibres). Along with the tensor fasciae latae, the muscle stabilises the knee through the iliotibial tract. It supports both the hip and the knee when these joints are slightly flexed. It is an antigravity muscle as well.

Its blood supply is from the inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

Pearl PM2282: Gluteal Muscles

 

Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: 3. Dura when inflamed under the part marked by the arrow gets the referred pain at:
questions.solution:
The part labelled in the image is the posterior cranial fossa. When dura of the posterior cranial fossa gets inflamed, there is referred pain at the back of head and neck region. 

The cranial dura mater is innervated mainly by branches of the three divisions of the trigeminal nerve, namely:

* Ophthalmic division (V1)- tentorial branch

* Maxillary division (V2)- nervus meningeus medius

* Mandibular division (V3)- nervus spinosus

The nerve branches supplying the dura mater in each cranial fossa are:



However, the posterior cranial fossa also gets sensory supply from the C2, C3 fibres distributed by hypoglossal nerve and C2 fibres distributed by vagus nerve. These sensory nerve endings are confined to the dura mater and cerebral blood vessels, and are absent in the brain parenchyma itself, as well as in the arachnoid and pia mater. Stimulation of these dural nerve endings can lead to headache or pain, often perceived in distant areas due to referred pain mechanisms.

Since the skin over the back of the neck and scalp is innervated by the medial branches of the dorsal rami of C2 (greater occipital nerve) and C3 (third occipital nerve), inflammation of the dura in the posterior cranial fossa may produce referred pain to these cutaneous areas — the back of the head and neck.

questions.text: 4. The area marked by the arrow in the given histopathological image can influence the surrounding cells by:
questions.solution:
The area marked by the arrow in the given histopathological image is Islets of Langerhans and it can influence the surrounding cells by paracrine effect. 

The endocrine pancreas is in the form of numerous rounded collections of cells that are embedded within the exocrine part. These collections of polyhedral cells are called Islets of Langerhans. They appear as groups of small cells with lightly stained cytoplasm. Each islet is separated from the surrounding alveoli by a thin layer of reticular tissue and are very richly supplied with blood through a dense capillary plexus.

The Islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells as follows

* α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 

* β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 

* δ or D cells- peripherally placed like α cells and secrete somatostatin and gastrin



While islet hormones maintain systemic homeostasis, they also critically regulate cells within the islet through paracrine signaling mechanisms to fine-tune cell function and survival.  In paracrine signaling, the signaling molecules released by a cell only affect target cells in close proximity to it. The densely packed nature of islet cells and blood vessels facilitates a paracrine signaling network mediated by proximity, cell contact via gap junctions, and local blood flow. Other examples of paracrine signaling include enteroendocrine cells of gastrointestinal tract. 

The below image shows the different types of extracellular cell-to-cell communication mechanisms.

questions.text:
5. Match the following:

 

1 A. Recieves oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins
2 B. Present to the right side of ascending aorta 
3 C. Hypertrophied in Pulmonary stenosis 
4 D. Arising from the left ventricle
questions.solution:
In the transverse section, the structures marked are :

* Aorta

* Left Atrium

* Right Atrium

* Right Ventricle

Hence, the correctly matched pairs are: 

1. Aorta D. Arising from the left ventricle
2. Left Atrium A. Receives oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins
3. Right atrium B. Present to the right side of ascending aorta
4. Right Ventricle C. Hypertrophied in Pulmonary stenosis

questions.text:
6. Which among these are supplied by the deep branch of ulnar nerve?

a. Flexor carpi ulnaris

b. Opponens digiti minimi

c. Third lumbricals

d. Fourth dorsal interossei
questions.solution:
Opponens digiti minimi, third lumbricals, fourth dorsal interossei are supplied by the deep branch of ulnar nerve.

The ulnar nerve arises from the ventral rami of C8 and T1. It runs downwards with the brachial artery and descends on the back of medial epicondyle of humerus where it can be palpated. In the forearm, it passes between two heads of flexor carpi ulnaris and gives off two muscular branches to the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor carpi ulnaris, along with dorsal cutaneous branch for medial half of dorsum of hand and palmar cutaneous branch for medial one-third of palm.

At the distal border of flexor retinaculum, the nerve divides into its superficial and deep branches. The superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis and gives digital cutaneous branches to the medial 1½ digits, including medial 1½ nail beds till the distal interphalangeal joints.

The deep branch supplies the following intrinsic muscles of the hand and finally ends in adductor pollicis.  

Muscle Action
Adductor pollicis Adducts the thumb
Abductor digiti minimi    Abducts little finger
Flexor digiti minimi Flexes little finger
Opponens digiti minimi  Pulls fifth metacarpal forward as in cupping the palm
Third and fourth Lumbricals    Flex metacarpophalangeal joints,extend interphalangeal joints
Palmar interossei  Adduct fingers towards centre of third digit or middle finger 
Dorsal interossei Abduct fingers from centre of third digit




The sensory supply of the ulnar nerve is shown below:

questions.text:
7. Which among the following muscles are supplied by the superficial branch of peroneal nerve?

a. Peroneus longus   b. Peroneus tertius  c. Peroneus brevis d. Extensor hallucis longus
questions.solution:
The superficial branch of the peroneal (fibular) nerve innervates only the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis muscles (Option a and c).

  Superficial peroneal  nerve Deep peroneal  nerve
Motor innervation

  • Peroneus Brevis
  • Extensor digitorum longus 
  • Extensor digitorum brevis
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius
Sensory innervation
  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

 
  • The first interdigital space
 


The course of the common peroneal nerve is shown below:

questions.text: 8. Which one of the following is the action of the muscle attached in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the lateral pterygoid plate and the muscle attached to it is the lateral pterygoid muscle, whose function is depression of the mandible. 

Lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Actions of the lateral pterygoid muscle are:

* Depresses the mandible (opens the mouth)

* Protrudes the mandible forward

* Side-to-side movements (for grinding action)



Pearl PM2400: Muscles of mastication

questions.text: 9. Identify the marked arrow in the given image:
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the respiratory bronchiole. It has simple cuboidal epithelial lining lacking cilia and goblet cells with outpockets communicating with the alveoli.

Terminal bronchioles represent the most distal parts of the conducting passage. Each terminal bronchiole ends by dividing into respiratory bronchioles. Terminal bronchioles contain cilia and stratified columnar epithelium, whereas respiratory bronchioles contain few or no cilia, and simple cuboidal epithelium. Another differentiating point between the two is that terminal bronchioles would not communicate with the alveoli but respiratory bronchioles would have a communication with the alveoli. (Option B)

Each respiratory bronchiole ends by dividing into a few alveolar ducts. Each alveolar duct ends in a passage, the atrium, which leads into a number of rounded alveolar sacs. Each alveolar sac is studded with a number of air sacs or alveoli and are lined by simple squamous epithelium. (Option D)

Bronchi and bronchioles can be distinguished by the presence of cartilage and glands in the bronchi which are not present in the bronchioles. (Option C)

The different respiratory zones of the lungs is shown below:



The image below shows the histology of lungs:



The coloured strips in the following illustration represent the location of different cells/structures in the trachea and bronchial tree:

questions.text: 10. Which of the following nerves is not involved in olfaction?
questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve is not involved in olfaction.

The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) is a purely motor nerve that innervates the muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). It does not carry any sensory or special sensory (smell) fibers, and it has no anatomical or functional connection to the olfactory system. Therefore, it plays no role in the sense of smell. The other three cranial nerves—trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves are mixed cranial nerves and contribute to olfaction.

Other options:

Option A: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), particularly its ophthalmic and maxillary divisions, is involved in olfaction indirectly. While it does not detect odors, it carries general sensory information like pain, touch, and temperature from the nasal mucosa. Trigeminal fibers can detect noxious chemicals (like ammonia and sulphur dioxide), contributing to the perception of irritation or burning, which complements the sense of smell.

Option B: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries general sensation from the pharynx and larynx and can respond to strong irritants. Vagal nerve stimulation has been shown to modify the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

Option C: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) carries taste and general sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. While it is primarily involved in gustation, it can be indirectly involved in olfaction and contribute to the overall flavour of food.

Pearl PM2242: Functional components of cranial nerves

Functional components of cranial nerves 
Oculomotor: CN-3
  • Extraocular skeletal muscles – GSE
  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11
  • Motor to 6th arch (through vagus) - Br E
  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12
  • Motor to lingual muscles – GSE


abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.
